Datset File Name:: Link to Publically Available Data (if applicable):

e1994CommercialLicensesNCCB.csv: Just provided the csv file on NCGA NCC Fisheries and Habitat Study>Timeseries/indicator analysis>Data

Fiscal Year, Standard Commerical Fishing, Retired Standard Commercial Fishing, Shellfish for NC residents, Commerical Fish Vessel Registration, Land or Sell, Fish Dealer, Endorsement to Sell (ETS), Tournament, Land Flounder, Ocean Pier, Spotter Plane, Menhaden for NonResident, Total

Datset File Name:: Does dataset include information governed under IRB or HIPAA?

e1994CommercialLicensesNCCB.csv: Dealer – Seafood Dealer – all commercially caught fish that are sold must go through a licensed seafood dealer.
ETS – Endorsement to Sell – This is the old commercial fishing license
SCFL – Standard Commercial Fishing License – This is the new commercial fishing license
RSCFL – Retired Standard Commercial Fishing License – For commercial fishermen 65 or older, a less expensive version of the SCFL
Shellfish w/o SCFL – Available to NC residents, allows fishermen to harvest shellfish commercially without having a SCFL

For both of these data sets, it may be important for your purposes to consider the difference between an issued license and a license actively used in fishing. People hold onto licenses that they don’t actually use for a variety of reasons. If you are going to look at effort or anything having to do with the number of participants involved in commercial fishing in North Carolina, it’s important to keep that in mind. If you get to a point in your analyses where you need active participant data, I’ll be happy to run that for you.
